# üá±üá∞ Sri Lanka This Week

![LastUpdated](https://img.shields.io/badge/last_updated-2025--11--21_06:18:40-green)
[![RSS](https://img.shields.io/badge/RSS-Feed-orange)](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/nuuuwan/lk_news_digest/refs/heads/main/rss.xml)

*Generated by gpt-5 from 182 English News Articles published between 2025-11-14 and 2025-11-21.*

## 1. Budget 2026 marries IMF discipline to cautious relief, but tax design and wage politics test credibility

The 2026 Budget keeps Sri Lanka on the rails of its IMF (International Monetary Fund) programme: a primary surplus, tighter public investment choices and a pivot to digital tax administration. The move to lower the VAT (Value-Added Tax) registration threshold to Rs. 36 million broadens the net, while the continued 2.5% SSCL (Social Security Contribution Levy) alongside VAT risks double‚Äëtaxing the same base and squeezing SMEs‚Äô cashflow. A headline pledge to lift plantation workers‚Äô take‚Äëhome pay via a Rs. 200/day state-funded attendance incentive has run into a legal challenge‚Äîcritics argue the Treasury cannot subsidise private-sector wages. Debt arithmetic remains tight, even as authorities say future ISB (International Sovereign Bond) service is ‚Äúmanageable‚Äù. The test now is execution: clean tax design, lawful wage support, and project selection that protects scarce fiscal space.

## 2. Corporate profits recover as stability returns, but demand is patchy and capital markets remain thin

Big listed groups reported stronger earnings‚ÄîDialog Axiata‚Äôs EBITDA rose 40% YTD, Hayleys kept profit growth, Aitken Spence lifted PBT 42%, and banks such as BOC and Sampath posted double‚Äëdigit PAT gains‚Äîsignalling cost control and easing macro stress. Yet textile exporter Teejay flagged weak global demand, and CSE liquidity stayed soft despite JF Packaging‚Äôs strong IPO debut. Sentiment improved after SriLankan Airlines struck a deal to restructure its defaulted bonds, but turnover remains brittle. This is a ‚Äúnormalisation without exuberance‚Äù: profitability is up, volumes and investment still lag.

## 3. SOE reform and PPPs will be judged by the first deals‚Äînot by policy speeches

The new PPP (public‚Äëprivate partnership) law and CEB unbundling are necessary, but investors will price Sri Lanka on project quality, risk sharing and delivery. Deloitte‚Äôs Asia team warned that exchange‚Äërate risk and under‚Äëprepared pipelines deter capital; ticket sizes under $50‚Äì100m will struggle to attract long‚Äëterm funds. India‚Äôs experience‚ÄîMOUs with performance targets, listed SOEs paying steady dividends‚Äîshows reform credibility compels capital. Sri Lanka‚Äôs early PPPs must come with bankable feasibility, fair risk allocation and transparent procurement, or private finance will wait on the sidelines.

## 4. Gulf and regional ties deepen: councils, flights and forums rebuild the external engine ‚úàÔ∏è

Sri Lanka launched the Sri Lanka‚ÄìSaudi Arabia Business Council; hosted a Luxembourg investment seminar; and co‚Äëconvened a Korea‚ÄìSri Lanka investment forum to fix bottlenecks. Oman invited Sri Lankan capital into logistics, tourism and manufacturing under Vision 2040, while Belavia‚Äôs Minsk‚ÄìMattala route broadens air links. Vietnam‚Äôs embassy probed opportunities in the Northern Province. These are small but cumulative steps to diversify partners and services‚Äîtourism, education, ICT and light manufacturing‚Äîbeyond slow‚Äëmoving merchandise exports.

## 5. Digital rails are being laid‚Äîfrom Google Pay to shrimp-farm data‚Äîbut equity and upkeep will decide outcomes

Commercial Bank became the first to enable Google Pay with Visa tokenisation; FAO and the Fisheries Ministry launched SIIS, a farm‚Äëto‚Äëregulator shrimp aquaculture platform using IoT/AI; and Dialog showcased 5G use‚Äëcases at INFOTEL. These are the right pipes for a modern economy. But as experts reminded, devices, teacher training, maintenance and rural connectivity determine whether platforms lift productivity or become stranded assets. The same governance lesson applies elsewhere: instead of curbing the RTI (Right to Information) Act, strengthening the Information Commission‚Äôs staffing and budgets would protect transparency gains.

## 6. Tourism‚Äôs next chapter must prioritise higher-yield niches, not raw volume

With arrivals rebounding, industry voices argued for ‚Äòniche excellence‚Äô over mass marketing: hiking (Pekoe Trail), wellness, design and architecture, birding, agro‚Äëexperiences, and slow rail can disperse visitors, deepen local spend and protect carrying capacity. New air links help, but success hinges on basics‚Äîwaste and water systems, signage, trail stewardship, trained guides‚Äîand careful storytelling that filters for intent, not just clicks. In short: shift from beach‚Äëand‚Äëselfie to purpose‚Äëdriven trips with higher retention and lower ecological stress.

## 7. Agri‚Äëindustry contradictions: palm oil, poultry feed and estate wages expose policy trade‚Äëoffs

A data‚Äërich case to replace Sri Lanka‚Äôs crude palm oil cultivation ban with regulated licensing notes higher yields and lower land/water footprints versus substitutes; meanwhile, a Rs. 25/kg SCL on imported maize keeps feed costs high, hobbling a technologically advanced poultry sector. Both policies depress competitiveness and raise consumer prices. On plantations, wage justice is overdue, but a fiscal workaround via Treasury incentives risks setting precedent without fixing productivity, land use and value‚Äëaddition. Coherent agri policy would pair fair wages with yield‚Äëraising investment, smarter trade taxes and environmental safeguards.

## 8. Carbon markets and the blue economy beckon‚Äîbut only if measurement and permitting are credible üåø

The Environment Ministry pitched carbon credits as a $250‚Äì300m annual opportunity within a decade, with mangroves, forests and renewables as anchors. Concurrently, academics urged a science‚Äëled ‚Äòblue economy‚Äô: PPP‚Äëready ports and logistics, aquaculture with biosecurity, and a marine research station at Kachchativu to depoliticise fisheries and rebuild stocks. Both agendas demand rigorous baselines, transparent registries, clear user rights and inter‚Äëagency coordination‚Äîor they risk becoming slide‚Äëdeck aspirations rather than exportable assets.

## 9. Procurement optics matter: the double‚Äëcab tender and RTI anxiety risk eroding public trust

A plan to procure 1,775 double‚Äëcab pickups has drawn scrutiny over compressed bidding windows and eligibility filters that could limit competition, while civil society warns against amending the RTI law instead of resourcing the Information Commission. For a government elected on integrity and thrift, procurement transparency and openness to scrutiny are as important as macro metrics. Rebuild credibility by publishing tender justifications, timelines and contracts, and by empowering oversight bodies.

## Model Prompt (for [gpt-5](https://platform.openai.com/docs/models/gpt-5))

```
You will be given several Sri Lankan news articles from the past week. Write a concise, cohesive editorial digest in the style of The Economist, but output it as a JSON list. Each list element must be a dict of the form:

{
  "title": "...",
  "body": "..."
}

Titles should be written as crisp, fully informative sentences. Follow each title with a short paragraph in "body" that adds context and nuance without bullets.

Go beyond summary and analyse how the week‚Äôs developments fit together. Use emojis purposefully, and explain any non-obvious acronyms or jargon. Stick strictly to verifiable facts.
```
